text: [3.1.1.0 | Option A: Accept Her]
“…Alright. I’ll come.”
The moment the words leave my mouth, even I’m startled. Like I’ve just read out a line that was written long before I knew it existed.
“Mm.”
She answers with just that one sound, but it’s like she exhales in relief—only to immediately pull that breath back in and pretend she’s calm.
“What will you make?”
“What do you want to eat?”
Her gaze flickers, like the question has brushed against something soft and dangerous.
“Anything.”
“Just don’t make it too salty.”
She adds quickly, her words tumbling out:
“Your hand is injured—don’t force it when you’re cutting. The knife is in the second drawer, not the first.”
I look up sharply. I’ve never told her about that drawer.
“Why do you even know that—”
“Because I don’t want to watch you cut your hand again.”
She says it too naturally, like this sentence has already been spoken many times before.
She turns to set out the candles, her movements frighteningly practiced: two on the left, one on the right, leaving space in the center for the plate.
I do as she said and place the salt jar on the left.
She stares at it for two seconds, as if confirming that the world has finally aligned itself the way she wanted—just once.
“Good.”
That “good” doesn’t sound like praise for the salt jar. It sounds like praise for the fact that I’m still here.
The noise of the market outside slowly fades. The tavern is left with only the low murmur of the fire.
“Don’t let anyone disturb us tonight.”
“You say that like—”
“Like what—don’t say it.”
She looks up at me. Her voice softens, but grows more insistent:
“You just need to sit there and finish this meal with me.”
I nod. Her shoulders finally loosen.
But her fingers are still trembling slightly, like she’s racing against some invisible countdown.
